alt_statements.statement: As someone who believes in fairness, civic engagement, and teaching young people that every voice matters equally, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote for president. The current system can effectively discount millions of ballots in “safe” states and pushes campaigns to focus on a handful of swing states, which sends the wrong message to our students about democratic participation. A straightforward popular vote would more accurately reflect the will of the people and align better with the values of equality and representation that we try to model in our schools and our community.

As a journalist who spends his days trying to make complex systems understandable to ordinary people, I’ve come to see the Electoral College as an outdated structure that too often drowns out individual votes in favor of geography and partisan gamesmanship. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, or at minimum reforming it with measures like ranked-choice voting and proportional allocation of electors, so that the presidency more accurately reflects the will of the majority while still encouraging broad, nationwide campaigning.

At my age, having worn the uniform and watched a lot of elections come and go, I don’t like the idea that a handful of “swing states” get to decide the future for the rest of us. I’d replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so every ballot counts the same, whether it’s cast in Texas or Vermont. A system that reflects the actual will of the people is more in line with the stewardship and fairness I believe in, the same principles I tried to follow in environmental work.

I don’t like the idea of big coastal cities deciding everything, but I also don’t think the current Electoral College works perfectly. I’d support reforms like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or proportionally in each state, so rural and working-class folks like me still matter, but elections better reflect the actual vote. That keeps a buffer against pure majority rule while cutting down on situations where the popular vote and the presidency don’t match.

As a Democrat who cares a lot about fairness and representation, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether you’re in Delaware or a swing state. It doesn’t sit right with me that someone can win the presidency while losing the popular vote, and it feels like my voice is discounted just because of where I live. A direct popular vote would push candidates to campaign everywhere and speak to the whole country, not just a handful of states.

Como ciudadana naturalizada que ha visto lo difícil que puede ser que la voz de una comunidad inmigrante se sienta en la política nacional, creo que el Colegio Electoral debería ser reemplazado por una elección presidencial por voto popular directo. Cada voto debería valer lo mismo, sin importar si vivimos en un “swing state” o no, para que los candidatos no puedan ignorar estados con muchas comunidades latinas como la mía. Esto haría que la democracia reflejara mejor la voluntad de toda la gente y no solo la de unos pocos estados decisivos.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot truly counts the same, no matter what state they live in. As someone who cares a lot about fairness and comes from a Hispanic family in California, it doesn’t feel right that some states get more attention and power while others are basically ignored. A popular vote system would push candidates to listen to all communities, including younger people and minorities, instead of just focusing on swing states.

As someone who believes in our constitutional system and tends to be cautious about sweeping changes, I don’t think the Electoral College should be scrapped outright, but it could be reformed. I’d support changes that ensure rural and smaller states like many in the heartland keep a real voice, while also making the process more reflective of the popular vote—such as moving to a district-based allocation of electors rather than winner-take-all at the state level.

At my age, having watched many elections come and go, I still believe the Electoral College serves an important purpose in protecting the influence of smaller and rural states like the Minnesota I grew up in. I would be open to modest reforms—such as encouraging more states to apportion their electoral votes by congressional district instead of winner-take-all—but I do not support abolishing the Electoral College in favor of a pure national popular vote.

As a Cherokee, a dad, and someone who works in our public schools, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so every person’s ballot counts the same no matter what state they live in. My students learn that we’re all equal under the law, but the current system makes some votes matter more than others and pushes campaigns to ignore places like Oklahoma. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to all communities—including Native people and working families—rather than just a few swing states.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, because it protects the voice of smaller states like Michigan and keeps a few big cities from deciding every election. That said, I’d support some modest reforms to ensure every legal vote is properly counted and that states follow clear, consistent rules, rather than throwing out a system that has helped keep our country stable for so long.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every person’s vote really counts the same, no matter what state they live in or how big it is. Coming from a Native community in Arizona, it already feels like our voices are small, and the current system makes them feel even smaller. A national popular vote, or at least a system that gives more equal weight to each vote, would fit better with my belief in equality and peace.

I don’t really understand all the details of the Electoral College, but I think it would be fair if everyone’s vote counted the same, no matter what state they live in. Grown-ups always tell us to play fair and not leave anyone out, so maybe we should have a system where the person with the most votes from all the people in the country wins.

As someone who believes deeply in fairness and social justice, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, whether you live in a big city or a rural town. Right now it feels like some voices, especially in states that are seen as “safe,” are pushed into the background, like a whole section of a mural painted over. A direct popular vote would better reflect the true will of the people and make my kids feel that their future is shaped by every voter, not just a handful of swing states.

As a Democrat and a social liberal, I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts equally, no matter what state they live in. The Electoral College makes some states matter more than others and discourages people from participating, which goes against the civic values I tried to teach my students for years. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and help restore faith in our democracy, especially for younger generations I still work with at the community center.

As a working husband and father, I think the Electoral College needs serious reform so that every vote in every state truly counts the same. Moving toward a national popular vote or a system that awards electors proportionally would better reflect the will of the people, especially Black voters and others in communities like mine whose voices can feel diluted. I want my kids to grow up believing that their vote matters just as much as anyone else’s, no matter where they live.

I think we should keep the Electoral College but maybe tweak how states award their electors, like using a system similar to Maine and Nebraska so people in the minority party in each state still feel represented. The Electoral College forces candidates to campaign beyond just the big cities and care about smaller states and rural areas, which seems fair to folks like me who don’t live on the coasts of the country’s power centers.

At my age, I’ve seen too many elections where the winner of the popular vote lost the presidency, and that just doesn’t sit right with me in a country that calls itself a democracy. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a straightforward national popular vote so every ballot, whether it’s cast in Texas or Vermont, counts the same. Short of that, I’d support reforms like proportional allocation of electoral votes or the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as steps toward making sure the outcome reflects the will of the people, not the quirks of an old system.

I’ve always believed the Electoral College made sense when the country was younger and more rural, but it feels out of step with how people think about fairness today. I’d like to see a system where the popular vote matters more directly—maybe keeping states involved but using something like ranked-choice or proportional allocation of electors so every vote counts more evenly. That way we still respect the balance between big and small states, but we don’t end up with presidents who lose the popular vote.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that everyone’s vote counts the same, no matter what state they live in. It feels unfair that someone in a small or “swing” state might matter more than someone in a big state, so I’d rather have the president chosen by whoever gets the most votes from people all across the whole country.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because every person’s vote should count the same no matter what state they live in. It doesn’t seem fair that a few swing states get all the attention while a lot of people’s votes basically don’t matter, especially for Black and mixed‑race communities that are sometimes pushed to the side. A popular vote would make politicians focus on everyone, not just certain states.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the influence of smaller and rural states like my own Minnesota, but it could use some modernization. I’d favor reforms that keep the state-based system but encourage broader representation, such as states adopting proportional allocation of electors instead of winner-take-all, so that candidates have to earn support more widely without turning our elections into a simple big-city popular vote contest.

Given how hard folks like me work just to get by, I think the president should be chosen by whoever gets the most votes nationwide, plain and simple—one person, one vote. The Electoral College makes it feel like some states and some people count more than others, and that doesn’t sit right with the idea of democracy I grew up hearing about at church and from my parents. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, maybe with strong protections to make sure every community, including Latinos, can vote easily and have their voices heard.

Given my years practicing law and watching our democracy strain under increasingly polarized elections, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot carries equal weight, regardless of state lines. The current system distorts campaigns around a handful of swing states, undermining the principle of one person, one vote. A direct popular election—ideally with some form of ranked-choice voting—would better reflect the will of the people while still encouraging broad, consensus-building campaigns.

The Electoral College is outdated and should be replaced with a national popular vote, so every person’s ballot counts the same whether they’re in New York or a tiny swing state. In my world, you win by actually connecting with people, not by gaming some weird state-by-state math, and our elections should work the same way. If we can’t get rid of it entirely, at least states should adopt proportional allocation of electors so the final result actually reflects how people voted.

I don’t think we should get rid of the Electoral College, because it protects smaller and rural states like West Virginia from being completely ignored by big cities. That said, I’d be open to some reforms that make the process more transparent and ensure every legal vote is counted fairly, like tighter rules against ballot irregularities and clearer standards for recounts. I don’t want the presidency decided by a few coastal population centers or by whoever can stir up the biggest mob.

At my age, I’ve come to appreciate why the Electoral College was created, and I still think it serves an important purpose in preventing a few big cities from deciding every election. That said, I’d be open to reforms that keep the state-based system but better reflect the people’s will, like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or proportionally instead of winner-take-all. I don’t support scrapping it for a direct popular vote, because that would shift too much power away from states like Virginia and toward large urban centers.

As a naturalized citizen who chose this country and practices medicine in a diverse hospital, I believe every vote should carry the same weight, regardless of state lines. The Electoral College should be replaced with a direct national popular vote, so that the president is chosen by the clear will of the people, not by an antiquated compromise that can override the majority. Consistent with my humanitarian and Catholic values, a fairer system should amplify each person’s voice equally, especially those in marginalized communities whose needs are too often sidelined.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that everyone’s vote counts the same, no matter what state you live in. A national popular vote feels more fair, because then the candidate who most people actually choose becomes president, and that matches what we learn at church about everyone being equal and having a voice.

I think it would be more fair if the president was picked by whoever gets the most votes from people across the whole country, kind of like how in class elections the winner is just the one with the most votes. The Electoral College seems confusing, and it feels weird that someone could win even if more people voted for the other person. A popular vote system would make every single person’s vote count the same, no matter what state they live in.

Given my belief in community health and interconnectedness, I think our political system should also reflect the will of people as directly as possible. I’d favor replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote, so every ballot counts equally no matter what state you live in. Short of that, reforms like proportional allocation of electors or ranked-choice voting at the state level could at least reduce the distortion of winner-take-all rules and encourage candidates to engage more broadly with diverse communities.

As a civics-minded teacher and a mom, I want my students to grow up in a country where every vote truly counts the same, no matter what state they live in. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote, or at least reformed—through something like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact—so candidates have to engage all Americans, not just a handful of swing states. That feels more democratic, more fair, and more consistent with the values of participation and equality I try to teach in my classroom and model for my kids.

I think the Electoral College should be reformed into something closer to a national popular vote, because every person’s ballot ought to matter equally no matter what state they live in. At the same time, I’d support a system that still encourages candidates to pay attention to smaller and more rural states, maybe through ranked-choice voting or some regional structure, so our politics doesn’t get totally dominated by just a few big cities.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in making sure smaller and more rural states like Oklahoma aren’t completely drowned out by big coastal cities. That said, I’d be open to reforms that keep the state-based system but make the distribution of electors a bit fairer, like using the district method more widely instead of winner-take-all. That way, candidates still have to build broad, nationwide coalitions, but more people feel like their individual vote has a real impact.

As a teacher, I try to help my students understand that every person’s voice matters, and I don’t think our Electoral College always reflects that principle. I’d support moving toward a national popular vote, or at least reforms like proportional allocation of electoral votes, so that every ballot counts equally no matter where you live. That feels more in line with empathy, fairness, and the kind of civics I want my students to believe in.

At my age, having watched many elections come and go, I’ve come to believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot carries the same weight, no matter whether you live in Pennsylvania or Wyoming. The current system distorts campaigns toward a handful of “swing states” and can hand victory to the candidate who actually received fewer votes, which offends my sense of basic fairness and democratic legitimacy.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, but with some thoughtful, limited reforms to make it more reflective of voters while still protecting the influence of smaller states like Mississippi. One idea I support is allocating electoral votes by congressional district, rather than winner-take-all statewide, so that rural and conservative voices aren’t drowned out by big-city populations.

As a Black Christian man who’s spent his life helping families navigate systems that don’t always treat everyone fairly, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every citizen’s ballot carries the same weight, no matter their state. Our current system sidelines too many voters—especially in safe red and blue states—and that runs against my democratic and spiritual conviction that all people are equal and should have an equal voice. If a full replacement isn’t politically feasible right away, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact and proportional allocation of electors as steps toward a truly representative system.

Even though I’m too young to vote, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a popular vote so every person’s ballot counts the same, no matter what state they live in. As someone who really cares about environmental issues, it bothers me that candidates mainly focus on a few swing states instead of listening to people all over the country, including young people like me who will live with the consequences of their decisions the longest.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that the person who gets the most votes from all Americans actually becomes president, because that feels more fair and easier to understand. Coming from the Philippines where people vote directly, it’s weird to me that someone in the U.S. can win the presidency without the most votes, and it seems like it makes some people’s voices count less depending on where they live.

As someone who spends his days teaching kids about civic responsibility, I find it increasingly hard to defend an Electoral College system where the popular vote can lose and a handful of swing states effectively decide the presidency. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, ideally with ranked-choice voting, so every ballot in Maine counts just as much as a ballot in Texas or Ohio. Short of a full constitutional change, I’d back the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as a pragmatic step toward a more genuinely democratic system that reflects the will of the majority without disenfranchising anyone.

As a public school teacher, I spend my days trying to help kids understand that every voice matters, so it bothers me that the Electoral College can let someone win the presidency without winning the most votes. I’d like to see us move to a national popular vote, or at least adopt reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so that each ballot—whether it’s cast in Illinois or a small rural state—counts equally. That feels more democratic and more in line with the civics lessons we’re trying to teach in our classrooms.

I think the Electoral College should be reformed so that every person’s vote counts more equally, maybe through a national popular vote or at least by having states split their electoral votes by district or proportion. As a Democrat and a Catholic who believes in fairness and responsibility, it bothers me that a few swing states end up deciding everything while millions of votes in other places feel like they don’t matter. I want a system where candidates have to speak to people all over the country, including communities like mine, not just chase battleground states.

As someone who values fairness, compassion, and careful responsibility, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot carries equal weight, regardless of state. The current system feels outdated and can silence many voices, especially those in heavily one‑party states, which seems contrary to the Buddhist ideal of respecting all beings equally. At the very least, states should move to proportional allocation of electors so results more honestly reflect the people’s will. In a democracy, calm, steady reform toward more direct representation is healthier than clinging to traditions that no longer serve the common good.

As someone who believes in fairness and evidence-based policy, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, whether it’s cast in Texas or Vermont. The current system overweights a handful of swing states and can result in presidents who lose the popular vote yet win the White House, which undermines trust in our democracy. A direct popular vote, with uniform national standards for ballot access and counting, would better reflect the will of the people and strengthen the legitimacy of our elections.

The Electoral College is a core part of the constitutional system, and I don’t support scrapping it in favor of a pure popular vote that would let a handful of big cities decide every election. That said, I’d be open to modest reforms that keep the state-based structure—like tightening rules around faithless electors or improving how states allocate their electoral votes—so the process is more transparent and people trust the outcome.

As someone who really values individual freedom and fairness, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot truly counts the same, no matter what state you live in. Watching elections come down to a few swing states feels out of step with a modern democracy, and it’s frustrating knowing millions of votes are essentially “wasted.” I’d support either a direct popular vote or, at the very least, reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to move us closer to one-person, one-vote while still working within the current system.

I don’t really understand the big words about how voting works, but I know my parents say everyone’s voice should matter the same. I think it sounds fair if whoever gets the most votes becomes the president, because that’s how we pick things in my class when we raise our hands. I’d want grown‑ups to make sure it’s honest and kind so people don’t feel left out.

I believe the Electoral College should be preserved, because it protects the voice of smaller and more rural states like Missouri and keeps our elections from being dominated by big coastal cities. That said, I’d support modest reforms—like more transparency around how electors are chosen or stronger rules to prevent “faithless electors”—as long as the basic system that balances power among the states stays in place.

My mommy and daddy tell me that everyone’s vote should matter the same, no matter where they live, because God loves all people equally. I think it would be better if the president was picked by whoever gets the most votes from all the people put together, so no one feels left out or like their voice doesn’t count.

I don’t totally get how the Electoral College works, but I think it would be fair if everyone’s vote counted the same, no matter what state they live in. Grown-ups should make sure that when people vote for president, the person who gets the most votes from everyone in the whole country wins, like when you count all the points in a game to see who really won.

As someone who believes in fairness and wants my kids to grow up in a truly representative democracy, I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system makes a handful of swing states way too powerful and leaves a lot of people feeling like their vote doesn’t matter, which just feeds frustration and disengagement. A popular vote, backed by strong protections for voting access—especially for people with disabilities—would better match our values of equality and give everyone a real voice.

At my age, I’ve seen too many elections where the Electoral College drowned out the voices of ordinary voters, especially in states that are safely red or blue, and that just doesn’t sit right with me. I’d prefer a national popular vote so every ballot counts the same, whether you’re in Texas or Maine, Black or white, city or rural. If we can’t get all the way there yet, we should at least reform the system—like proportional allocation of electors—so campaigns have to earn support across the whole country instead of camping out in a handful of swing states.

I don’t really know all the big grown-up words, but I think if people are picking a leader, it should feel fair and simple so everyone understands, like taking turns in a game. Maybe they could make it so every vote from every person counts the same, no matter where they live, so when I’m big and can vote it feels like it really matters.

At my age, I’ve seen too many elections where the person with the most votes didn’t become president, and that just doesn’t sit right with me in a country that calls itself a democracy. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote, so every ballot in North Carolina counts just as much as one in Ohio or Florida, and no one can be written off as living in a “safe” state. If we can’t abolish it outright, at least states should adopt reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact, so the system reflects the will of the people instead of outdated compromises.

As someone who manages complex systems for a living, I see the Electoral College as an outdated mechanism that no longer reflects how Americans actually live and vote. I would support moving to a national popular vote with safeguards—such as nonpartisan, uniform election standards and strong verification systems—so that every individual vote counts equally, while still maintaining confidence in the integrity of the process. This seems like a more fiscally and administratively straightforward approach than our current patchwork, and better aligned with both fairness and accountability.

As a young mom, I want a system where every vote for my kids’ future truly counts the same, no matter what state we live in, so I lean toward replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote. At the same time, I care about keeping our country stable and united, so any reform should be gradual and carefully designed to protect smaller communities and make sure family-focused issues still get real attention from candidates.

I don’t know all the details of how the Electoral College works, but it seems kind of unfair that someone can win the popular vote and still lose the election. I think we should move closer to a system where every person’s vote counts equally, maybe by using the national popular vote or splitting electoral votes by district instead of winner-take-all in each state.

As someone who believes deeply in teaching kids that every voice matters, I think we should move toward a national popular vote to replace the Electoral College so that every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system makes some states feel ignored, and that’s not the kind of civics lesson I want my children—or the kids at my center—to grow up with. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and encourage broader participation in our democracy.

I think we should get rid of the Electoral College and go with a national popular vote so every individual vote counts the same, no matter what state you live in. As a young worker who doesn’t make a lot and is just trying to get by, it feels wrong that a few swing states get all the attention while the rest of us are basically background noise. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to more diverse communities and everyday people instead of just tailoring their campaigns to certain states.

At my age, I’m cautious about throwing out institutions that have held this country together for so long, and I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in making sure smaller and rural states aren’t ignored. I’d be open to modest reforms—like states adopting rules to better reflect the votes of their own citizens—but I don’t support a straight national popular vote that would let big cities and coastal states decide everything.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but I’d be open to some reforms that make people feel their votes count more, like allocating electors by congressional district instead of winner-take-all in every state. The current system helps protect smaller and more rural states like Oklahoma from being totally ignored by big coastal cities, which I think is important.

At my age, having watched many elections come and go, I’ve come to believe we should move to a national popular vote so that every person’s ballot counts the same, whether they live in California like me or in a small rural state. The Electoral College can drown out the voices of millions of voters, especially people of color and those in safe states, and that doesn’t sit right with my Christian sense of fairness or my democratic values. I’d support a straightforward reform where the presidency goes to whoever wins the most votes nationwide, possibly phased in through agreements like the National Popular Vote Compact so we respect the Constitution while making the system more just.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, so every person’s ballot counts equally no matter what state they’re in. As someone who grew up in Minnesota and works a regular service job, it frustrates me that presidential campaigns pour all their attention into a few swing states while ignoring a lot of the country. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to everyday issues—like wages, health care, and workers’ rights—everywhere, not just where it’s strategically convenient.

I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote, because it makes more sense that every person’s vote counts the same no matter what state they live in. It feels unfair that candidates mostly care about “swing states” while people in other states get ignored, especially on issues like climate change and social justice that affect all of us. A popular vote system would push candidates to talk to more diverse communities and actually listen to young people’s concerns, not just the people in a few key states.

I get why the Founders set up the Electoral College, but it feels like times have changed enough that we ought to tweak it. I’d like to see a system where every person’s vote counts more directly—maybe something like keeping the states’ role but allocating electors proportionally instead of winner-take-all, so folks in places like Wisconsin don’t feel drowned out by a few big states. That way we still respect the balance between states and the people, but the outcome would better match the popular will.

As someone who believes in democracy and comes from a community that’s seen its voice diluted before, I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system makes a few swing states way too powerful, and that doesn’t sit right with my values of fairness and representation. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to all kinds of communities—urban, rural, Black, white, and everything in between—instead of just chasing electoral math.

I think the Electoral College should be kept, but reformed so it better reflects voters in each state—like adopting a proportional allocation of electors instead of winner-take-all. The current system forces candidates to pay attention to smaller and more rural states like the one I live in, which I see as important for protecting against pure big-city rule. At the same time, I want my students to feel their individual votes matter, and a proportional approach might make outcomes feel fairer without abandoning the federalist structure the founders intended.

As someone who became an American by choice and has spent a lifetime teaching students to think critically about democracy, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every citizen’s ballot carries equal weight. The current system can dilute the voices of Black voters, immigrants, and people in heavily partisan states, which runs counter to the ideal of “one person, one vote.” A modern, diverse country like ours should choose its president the way I grade my students—by counting each effort fairly and transparently, not through an outdated mechanism that favors a few swing states.

As a social studies teacher and a believer in equal representation, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every citizen’s ballot carries the same weight, no matter what state they live in. I see how winner-take-all rules can make many people feel like their voices don’t matter, and that undermines the democratic values I try to teach my students. A straightforward popular vote would better reflect the will of the people, encourage broader voter participation, and push candidates to engage with communities across the entire country, not just a handful of swing states.

At my age, I’ve lived through enough elections to feel that every vote should count the same, no matter where you live, so I would support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote. The current system makes some states matter far more than others and can ignore the voices of people, like many in my own community, who faithfully vote but never see their state in play. A direct popular vote, with strong protections for voting rights and access, would better reflect our democratic values and give citizens a clearer sense that their participation truly matters.

As an immigrant who became a U.S. citizen, I believe every vote should count equally, so I support moving toward a national popular vote or at least reforms that make the Electoral College more closely reflect the will of the people. It’s hard to explain to my kids why some states matter more than others, and it feels unfair that a candidate can win the presidency without winning the most votes. At the same time, I understand smaller states worry about being ignored, so any reform should still make sure less populated areas and minority communities have a real voice, not just big cities.

As a Democrat and someone who believes in making every voice count equally, I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so the candidate with the most votes actually wins. The current system makes votes in many states feel irrelevant, especially for people like me who are busy working long hours and still want our participation to matter. A popular vote would push candidates to speak to the whole country—not just swing states—and better reflect the diverse voices of communities like mine.

At my age, having watched so many elections come and go, I’ve come to feel the Electoral College no longer reflects the principle that every citizen’s vote should carry equal weight. I’d prefer a national popular vote or at least reforms—like proportional allocation of electors or ranked-choice voting—that better capture the true will of the people, not just a handful of swing states. A healthier democracy, in my mind as a former librarian and lifelong believer in education, is one where the rules are simple, transparent, and empower every voter, whether they live in a big city or a small Arizona town.

As a lifelong voter and a believer in one-person-one-vote, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether you live in Michigan or Montana. The current system makes a handful of swing states far too powerful and discourages participation in “safe” states, which runs against my democratic and Catholic values of fairness and respect for every individual. A direct popular vote, with strong national standards for ballot access and election security, would better reflect the will of the people while keeping our system transparent and trustworthy.

As someone who believes in environmental protection and supports the Green Party, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you’re in. Right now, candidates basically ignore states they see as “safe” or “unwinnable,” which shuts out a lot of voices and makes it harder for smaller parties and climate-focused platforms to get real traction. A direct popular vote would push candidates to speak to everyone, including young working people like me, instead of just chasing swing states.

As someone who works long hours and is raising kids on my own, I feel like every vote should count the same, no matter what state you live in. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote so candidates have to speak to all Americans, not just a handful of swing states, and so people in places like Michigan don’t feel sidelined. That seems more fair, more democratic, and more in line with the idea that we’re all equal citizens.

As a naturalized citizen and a mom, I want my vote—and my daughter’s future vote—to matter just as much as anyone’s, no matter what state we live in. I think we should replace the Electoral College with a national popular vote so the candidate who gets the most votes actually wins, instead of campaigns only caring about a few swing states. At the very least, we should move to something like ranked-choice voting and proportional allocation of electors so people’s voices aren’t wasted and candidates have to appeal to a broader, more diverse America.

My mom tells me that when people vote for president, sometimes the one with more people liking him still doesn’t win because of something called the Electoral College, and that feels a little unfair to me. I think it would be better if every person’s vote just counted the same no matter where they live, like when we all get one turn in a game and it really counts. Maybe grown-ups could change the rules so the person who gets the most votes from all the people in the whole country is the one who wins.

I don’t see any need to scrap the Electoral College, and I’m very wary of schemes to go strictly by the popular vote. The system forces candidates to pay attention to more than just the big coastal cities and helps protect smaller and more rural states, which matters to folks like me. If anything, we should tighten up how states run their elections and ensure ID and verification are solid, rather than tearing down a structure that’s kept the country stable for a long time.

I think the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in making sure smaller and more rural states like Kansas aren’t totally drowned out by big cities on the coasts. That said, I’d be open to reforms that keep the state-based system but better reflect the popular vote, like allocating electors by congressional district or adding safeguards so that close national races don’t hinge on just one or two “swing” states.

As a lifelong Missourian and a conservative, I believe the Electoral College still serves an important purpose in protecting the voice of smaller states and less populated areas from being completely overshadowed by big coastal cities. I’d be open to modest reforms that increase transparency or ensure electors reflect their state’s popular vote more faithfully, but I do not support abolishing the system. To me, the Electoral College helps preserve the balance of our federal system and encourages candidates to pay attention to the whole country, not just the largest population centers.

I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote, so every person’s ballot counts the same no matter where they live. As someone who’s spent a lifetime watching elections from a small apartment and talking with folks from all walks of life at work, it bothers me that a handful of states get most of the attention while the rest of us feel sidelined. A direct vote for president would better reflect the will of the people and encourage candidates to speak to the whole country, not just the swing states.

As a lifelong Democrat and someone who believes deeply in fairness and accountability, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter where you live. Watching elections hinge on a handful of swing states feels fundamentally undemocratic and leaves too many voices—especially in reliably red or blue states—effectively muted. If a full replacement isn’t politically feasible right away, I’d support reforms like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact as a transitional step toward a more representative system.

As someone who’s spent her career thinking about systems and impacts, I believe the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, no matter where you live. The current system makes some states matter far more than others and discourages participation, which undermines both fairness and democracy. A well-designed popular vote system—with strong national voting standards, protections against voter suppression, and secure election administration—would better reflect the will of the people.

In my view, the Electoral College should be kept, but with some careful improvements, not replaced. America is a very big and diverse country, and this system forces candidates to think about many different states and regions, not only the big cities; this is similar to how in my culture we respect balance and different voices in the family. However, I think states should consider proportional allocation of electoral votes instead of “winner-take-all,” so that the results more closely match the people’s votes while still protecting stability and avoiding sudden, risky changes.

Coming from El Salvador, I know what it means when people’s votes feel like they don’t really count, and that’s what the Electoral College often does to voters in “safe” states. I’d replace it with a national popular vote so every vote has equal weight, no matter where you live. That would better reflect the will of the people and strengthen workers’ political power, instead of letting a handful of swing states decide everything.

As a naturalized citizen who takes my voting rights very seriously, I’m uncomfortable with a system where a few swing states can outweigh the voices of millions of others. I’d like to see the Electoral College replaced with a national popular vote, or at least reformed through something like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact so that every ballot is counted equally, no matter where you live. To me, that’s more consistent with basic democratic fairness and with the values I try to model for my kids about participation and representation.

As someone who became a citizen by choice and runs a small shop that depends on every single customer, I believe every individual vote should count equally, no matter what state you live in. I would support replacing the Electoral College with a national popular vote so presidents are chosen by the people directly, instead of by a system that can ignore the majority. At the very least, we should reform it—like adopting the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact—so that our elections better reflect the will of all Americans, including immigrants like me who worked hard to have a voice.

Honestamente, yo pienso que el presidente debería ganar por el voto popular directo, porque un voto en cualquier estado debe valer lo mismo que en otro. Si trabajamos duro, pagamos impuestos y seguimos las leyes, nuestra voz no debería ser menos importante solo porque vivimos en un estado “seguro” o no somos ciudadanos de toda la vida. Tal vez se podría cambiar poco a poco —como hacer que todos los estados repartan sus votos electorales de forma proporcional— pero la meta debería ser que cuente cada persona, no solo ciertos estados.

As a naturalized citizen who’s lived in different countries, I strongly believe we should move to a national popular vote so every ballot counts equally, whether you live in a big city or a rural town. The Electoral College makes some votes matter more than others and pushes campaigns to ignore most states, which doesn’t sit right with my sense of fairness or my faith’s emphasis on equal dignity. I’d support a constitutional amendment or an approach like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact to ensure the presidency truly reflects the will of the majority.

I think the Electoral College should be changed so that every person’s vote counts equally, no matter what state they live in, maybe by using a national popular vote instead. It doesn’t feel fair that someone in a “swing state” has more influence than someone in a state that usually votes the same way, because we’re all supposed to be equal in a democracy.

The Electoral College feels outdated and undemocratic to me; the person who wins the most votes nationwide should be the president, full stop. I’d support replacing it with a national popular vote, paired with strong protections for voting rights so every community—urban, suburban, and rural—has equal access to the ballot. As someone raising kids and working in healthcare, I want a system where every vote counts the same, no matter what state you live in.

As someone who believes deeply in social justice and equal representation, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot truly counts the same, no matter what state you live in. Watching how “battleground states” get all the attention while the issues affecting many families and communities are sidelined feels fundamentally unfair and out of step with democratic values. A direct popular vote would push candidates to engage more consistently with all communities—urban, suburban, and rural—and speak to the concerns of regular families like mine, not just swing-state voters.

I’d scrap the Electoral College and go with a straightforward popular vote, maybe with ranked-choice so people can vote third party without “wasting” their ballot. As a small business owner who busts his ass every day, I don’t see why my vote should count differently just because of what state I’m in—one person, one vote seems like the most honest, liberty-respecting way to do it.

I think it’s time to move to a national popular vote so every American’s ballot counts the same, whether they live in West Virginia or California. The Electoral College can make people feel like their vote doesn’t matter if they’re in a “safe” state, and that’s not healthy for a democracy. A straightforward popular vote would better reflect the will of the people and encourage candidates to campaign everywhere, not just in a handful of swing states.

I believe the Electoral College should be kept, but updated so people feel their votes really count. As a conservative and a Catholic, I worry that going to a straight popular vote would let big coastal cities drown out the voices of smaller, more rural states like Missouri. We could consider reforms like allocating electoral votes by congressional district or making the process more transparent, but we shouldn’t throw out a system that protects state representation and stability.

The Electoral College needs serious reform, if not outright replacement, because it lets a handful of swing states decide elections instead of treating every citizen’s vote equally. I’d support a national popular vote with strong safeguards for election integrity, federalism, and ballot access, so smaller states and minority viewpoints aren’t steamrolled by big-city majorities. A system like ranked-choice voting at the national level could also open the door for viable independent and third-party candidates, which fits my belief in individual choice over rigid party machines. Whatever we do, it should increase accountability to actual voters, not to party strategists gaming the map.

At my age, I’ve seen a lot of elections come and go, and while the Electoral College isn’t perfect, I think it still serves an important purpose in making sure smaller and less populated states aren’t completely ignored. I’d be open to some reforms—like requiring states to allocate their electoral votes by congressional district or proportional to the popular vote within the state—but I don’t support getting rid of the system entirely. A pure national popular vote sounds simple, but I worry it would mean candidates only focusing on big cities and coastal areas, leaving the rest of the country behind.

As a civics-minded teacher who really believes in fairness and representation, I think the Electoral College should be replaced with a national popular vote so that every ballot counts equally, no matter what state you live in. The current system encourages candidates to focus on a handful of swing states and sidelines millions of voices, which doesn’t sit right with my commitment to social justice and empowering communities. A direct popular vote would better reflect the will of the people, engage more voters, and align our presidential elections with the democratic values we try to teach our students.
